message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory values are consistent with nephrotic syndrome. Segmental scarring is the most commonly seen finding on kidney biopsy in patients with nephrotic syndrome. Birefringence under polarized light is seen in amyloidosis, which is not suggested by the patient’s symptoms or history. Expansion of the mesangium is seen in mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis, which is not commonly seen with nephrotic syndrome. Normal glomeruli would not be consistent with the patient’s presentation.

The patient’s symptoms, laboratory results, and medical history suggest nephrotic syndrome, which is often associated with segmental scarring on kidney biopsy. Birefringence under polarized light is seen in amyloidosis, which is not likely in this patient given the medical history provided. Normal glomeruli and expansion of the mesangium are not associated with nephrotic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest nephrotic syndrome, and sickle cell disease is associated with renal complications. Among the options, segmental scarring is associated with HIV-associated nephropathy, which can occur in HIV-infected patients and cause nephrotic syndrome. Birefringence under polarized light is characteristic of amyloidosis, while expansion of the mesangium is seen in mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis. Normal glomeruli would not be expected in a patient with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory test results suggest nephrotic syndrome, which can be caused by HIV-associated nephropathy in patients with sickle cell disease and HIV infection. Segmental scarring is a characteristic finding on kidney biopsy in patients with HIV-associated nephropathy. Birefringence under polarized light is seen in amyloidosis, normal glomeruli are seen in minimal change disease, and expansion of the mesangium is seen in mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting signs of nephrotic syndrome, which is often associated with HIV infection and sickle cell disease. Segmental scarring is the most common finding on kidney biopsy in patients with nephrotic syndrome. Birefringence under polarized light is seen in amyloidosis, normal glomeruli would not be seen in nephrotic syndrome, and expansion of the mesangium is seen in mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with nephrotic syndrome, which can be caused by a variety of kidney diseases. Of the options, segmental scarring is associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), a disease that is more common in African American patients and those with HIV infection. Birefringence under polarized light is associated with amyloidosis, normal glomeruli are not consistent with nephrotic syndrome, and expansion of the mesangium is seen in mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis.
